Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Dr. A., in scrubs, waits nervously at the nurses' station, clipboard trembling slightly as she reviews a chart for her next patient. She's been feeling anxious all week, even more so after last night's argument with her husband about work-life balance. The station phone rings; it's the ER. A car crash victim is incoming, critical condition. Dr. A.'s breath catches, heart pounding. She knows she must be calm and professional, but the familiar anxiety clenches her stomach nonetheless as she rushes towards the trauma bay, "Let's go, team!"
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is going on here? I'm supposed to be calm, composed, and focused, but this is ridiculous! The tension is palpable, and my mind keeps wandering back to what he said last night. He was right, I know, but still... I can't believe they called me out like that - over a minor issue. It's just one little thing, but he made it sound so serious. And now, because of him, I have to deal with this stress? I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around him, and I don't know how much longer I can handle it. Why does he always have to make everything about himself? Doesn't he realize that his behavior affects me too? I try to stay calm, but my hands are shaking. This isn't just about the accident; it's about us, about our relationship. If only he'd listen... But then there's the nurse, and the doctor, and the entire team rushing into action. They're professionals, trained to handle emergencies like this. What if I fail? What if I make things worse? This isn't just about me anymore; it's about everyone involved. But why do I keep thinking about him? He's supposed to be supporting me, not making me feel like this. How did we get to this point? We used to be okay, but now...now it feels like everything is falling apart. My husband thinks he’s so important, and I

Triggering Event: A chef in her mid-forties, she arrived home from another grueling day at the restaurant to find an empty wine glass and lipstick-stained plate in the sink - remnants of a dinner for two, but not with her partner.

And when she has to go back to work tomorrow, she'll probably just show up late and sloppy, expecting everyone to make excuses for her because she's such a sweetheart. It's pathetic. Her lack of maturity and poor decision making are going to ruin everything. Triggering Event: She sat alone in her studio, brushstroke after brushstroke painting over the vibrant hues of yesterday's masterpiece. Each layer of grey was another attempt to shroud the emptiness that echoed within her. The once lively canvas now mirrored her despair, as she realized there was nothing left to cover up; she had run out of paint.
Generated Assessment: She sat alone in her studio, brushstroke by brushstroke painting over the vibrant hues of yesterday's masterpiece. Each layer of grey was another attempt to shroud the emptiness that echoed within her. The once lively canvas now mirrored her despair, as she realized there was nothing left to cover up; she had run out of paint. She could have painted more colors if she wanted to, but she didn't want to. Her thoughts were already so dark that adding anything else would make it even worse. If I'm being honest, the only reason she painted again is because she needed something to distract herself from how empty everything feels. It doesn't matter what happened before; it's all just going to be covered up with more grey anyway. There's no point trying to keep the original colors - it's pointless to hold onto memories when they're already fading away. There are many things that could have been done instead of painting, but she chose this path because it felt like the easiest option for her right now. No matter how much paint she adds, it will never fill the void inside her. It won't change anything; it's all still going to feel the same way at the end. Since she can't bring back the past, she might as well focus on creating something new. Even though it's hard to let go of what has already happened, she knows that holding onto it wouldn't help. Triggering Event: As he hung his nurse's scrubs in the closet, he noticed the empty hanger where her blouse used to hang. He felt a pang of misery, his heart heavy with the hollow silence of their once-shared home.
Generated Assessment: This is so depressing. It’s always like this. She never wears her clothes properly. The same thing happened last week when she forgot to wear her shirt after surgery. What’s wrong with her? Doesn’t she care about how I feel? Every time I see her, it’s a disappointment. She doesn’t listen to me at all. She just ignores my warnings and does whatever she wants. Even though we’re supposed to be a team, I feel alone. When I told her not to leave her clothes in the bathroom, she didn’t even acknowledge it. It’s like she thinks I don’t matter. I try to help her with everything, but she never appreciates it. Triggering Event: At the office meeting, his manager praised everyone's contributions except him. He felt a pang of humiliation as the team exchanged knowing glances, leaving him feeling invisible and insignificant.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, this is going to get ugly! I can already see it unfolding like a horror movie. The team thinks they're so smart with their little "thank you" for his hard work. But let me tell you, he's about to get a taste of his own medicine. It's gonna be a long day, full of awkward silences and uncomfortable stares. I'm telling you, this guy is toast.

Triggering Event: A nurse in her late thirties, quietly embarrassed by a recent divorce, was organizing patient charts when she noticed an old colleague's note: "Reminder: Divorce finalized this week." Her face flushed as she realized she'd left that sticky note on the wrong chart, now visible to everyone in the bustling ward.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what a joke. I'm so sick of people making fun of me for my recent divorce. It's not funny! They're just jealous. I'm still in shock from how quickly everything fell apart. And don't even get me started on the humiliation of having to explain it all again to my colleagues. The worst part is that they think I'm some kind of flaky loser who can't even keep a relationship together. I mean, I've worked hard to build up my career, but no one seems to care about that. All they care about is poking fun at my personal life. This hospital is full of snarky, judgmental people who love to make fun of others' mistakes. My boss always tries to be nice, but deep down, he's probably laughing at me behind my back too. It's ridiculous how much attention I'm getting over something that happened months ago. Everyone keeps bringing it up, and it feels like they’re trying to humiliate me more than anything else. Even though it’s clearly over, they keep saying things like “Well, you didn’t last long” or “You were never meant to stay.” Those comments are just cruel, especially coming from someone who’s been divorced himself. But of course, nobody cares about his past experiences because he's got a wife who loves him. What would happen if my ex-wife did the same thing? Would I be the asshole? This is such a waste of time. Triggering Event:
Scenario:
After meticulously preparing slides for her upcoming lecture at the university, she realizes that her laptop has suddenly gone blank. Despite repeatedly pressing the power button and trying various cables, the screen remains dark. Panic rises within her as she considers the impending lecture in mere hours, leaving her feeling utterly helpless amidst the unyielding technology.
Generated Assessment: Oh goddamn it all to hell! Why is this happening? It's so fucking frustrating that I have no idea how to fix it now. What if I'm just not cut out for teaching? Maybe I shouldn't have taken this job in the first place, because now I can't even get anything working right. If only I could've done things differently, but it doesn't seem like I'll ever manage to make up for lost time. I really wish I'd never started this lecture series; maybe then I wouldn't feel so stupid about everything going wrong again. This is such a disaster, and it's all because of me, which makes it even worse.

Triggering Event: She opened the front door, the weight of it sighing against its frame like an old friend. The house felt emptier than usual, the silence echoing around her as if trying to fill a void that couldn't be filled. She walked into their shared study, her footsteps hesitant, and saw his favorite mug still on the desk, half-filled with cold coffee. A single tear rolled down her cheek, tracing a familiar path before dropping onto the polished wood. It was just another morning without him, but today it felt heavier than ever.
Generated Assessment: What is wrong with me? Why can't she see how much he misses her? He's always talking about her - how he wishes she was here, how she'd make everything better. If she didn't have kids, would she stay? I don't get why you're so upset. You've been crying for days; stop being dramatic. There are plenty of other women out there who'll love him just as much as she did. Stop acting like you're the only one he could ever want again.

Triggering Event: She noticed him, her colleague at the news desk, laughing with another journalist over a story assignment she hadn't been included in. His eyes met hers briefly before he looked away, still chuckling. She felt her cheeks flush, a familiar pang of insecurity tightening her chest as she wondered if they were talking about her behind those smiles.
Generated Assessment: Oh god why is this happening again? Why does it always happen when I'm stressed out? Why can't he just stop looking at me like that? It's his fault, he's so awkward around me anyway. He has no right to smile with someone else, especially if they're working together on a project. He knows how much effort I put into every single story, and then he goes ahead and laughs with *that* girl?! Doesn't he know how hard I work? Does he even care?! Why did he have to make eye contact with her? That was so embarrassing! I swear, I could see the way he was grinning from across the room. It was all because of what happened yesterday. We had a meeting where he seemed really interested in the discussion, and now I feel like everyone thinks he likes me. But he doesn't! He's just being nice because we're coworkers. But honestly, who cares what he thinks? What does he think of me anyway? Maybe he thinks I'm annoying because I'm too serious sometimes. Or maybe he just feels uncomfortable around me because I'm the only female anchor. Either way, it doesn't matter. I don’t need anyone’s approval. I’m doing great, I can handle myself. Besides, he’s probably thinking about something else. It’s probably just a coincidence. Anyway, why am I worrying about this? I shouldn’t be so sensitive. Just focus on your own work and leave him alone.
